Fubini's Theorem

Posted on 2021-06-28 Edited on 2024-03-12

Let (X,F1,μ1)(X, \mathcal{F}_1, \mu_1)(X,F1​,μ1​)
and (Y,F2,μ2)(Y, \mathcal{F}_2, \mu_2)(Y,F2​,μ2​)
be two σ\sigmaσ-finite measure space.

Produce Measure Space

Consider the product space Ω=X×Y\Omega = X \times YΩ=X×Y.

Definition. A measurable rectangle is a product A×BA \times BA×B for which A∈F1A \in \mathcal{F}_1A∈F1​ and B∈F2B \in \mathcal{F}_2B∈F2​.

Denote the collection of measurable rectangles as

S≐{A×B,A∈F1,B∈F2}. \mathcal{S} \doteq \begin{Bmatrix} A \times B, A \in \mathcal{F}_1, B \in \mathcal{F}_2 \end{Bmatrix}. S≐{A×B,A∈F1​,B∈F2​​}.

We would like to construct a measure μ\muμ on σ(S)\sigma(\mathcal{S})σ(S), the σ\sigmaσ-field generated by S\mathcal{S}S, thus

  1. For each A×B∈SA \times B \in \mathcal{S}A×B∈S, it’s natural to define μ(A×B)=μ1(A)⋅μ2(B)\mu (A \times B) = \mu_1(A) \cdot \mu_2(B)μ(A×B)=μ1​(A)⋅μ2​(B).

  2. We prove that S\mathcal{S}S is a semialgebra.

  3. We show that μ\muμ is a measure on S\mathcal{S}S.

  4. Finally, it follows by the Caratheodory’s Extension Theorem, μ\muμ has a unique extension on σ(S)\sigma(\mathcal{S})σ(S).

Lemma 1. S\mathcal{S}S is a semialgebra.

Proof.

  • S\mathcal{S}S is close under intersection: if A×B,C×D∈SA \times B, C \times D \in \mathcal{S}A×B,C×D∈S, then

    (A×B)∩(C×D)=(A∩C)×(B∩D). (A \times B) \cap (C \times D) = (A \cap C) \times (B \cap D). (A×B)∩(C×D)=(A∩C)×(B∩D).

  • The complement of element in S\mathcal{S}S is a finite disjoint union of elements in S\mathcal{S}S: if A×B∈SA \times B \in \mathcal{S}A×B∈S, since

    Ω=(A×B)+(Aˉ×B)+(A×Bˉ)+(Aˉ×Bˉ), \Omega = (A \times B) + ( \bar A \times B ) + ( A \times \bar B ) + ( \bar A \times \bar B ), Ω=(A×B)+(Aˉ×B)+(A×Bˉ)+(Aˉ×Bˉ),

    it holds that

    A×B‾=(Aˉ×B)+(A×Bˉ)+(Aˉ×Bˉ). \overline{ A \times B } = ( \bar A \times B ) + ( A \times \bar B ) + ( \bar A \times \bar B ). A×B​=(Aˉ×B)+(A×Bˉ)+(Aˉ×Bˉ).

□\square□

Lemma 2. μ\muμ is a measure on S\mathcal{S}S.

Proof. It suffices to prove σ\sigmaσ-additivity of μ\muμ.
Suppose A×B=+i≥1(Ai×Bi)A \times B = +_{i \ge 1} (A_i \times B_i)A×B=+i≥1​(Ai​×Bi​) is a countable disjoint union of elements in S\mathcal{S}S.

Fix an x∈Ax \in Ax∈A.
For each y∈By \in By∈B, we have (x,y)∈A×B(x, y) \in A \times B(x,y)∈A×B.
As the sets {Ai×Bi}\begin{Bmatrix} A_i \times B_i \end{Bmatrix}{Ai​×Bi​​} consists of a partition of A×BA \times BA×B, it follows that (x,y)(x, y)(x,y) belongs to exactly one Ai×BiA_i \times B_iAi​×Bi​.
Denote

I(x)≐{i:∃y∈B, s.t., (x,y)∈Ai×Bi}={i:x∈Ai}. I(x) \doteq \begin{Bmatrix} i : \exists y \in B,\, \text{s.t.},\, (x, y) \in A_i \times B_i \end{Bmatrix} = \begin{Bmatrix} i : x \in A_i \end{Bmatrix}. I(x)≐{i:∃y∈B,s.t.,(x,y)∈Ai​×Bi​​}={i:x∈Ai​​}.

Then B=+i∈I(x)BiB = +_{i \in I(x) } B_iB=+i∈I(x)​Bi​.

As μ2\mu_2μ2​ is a measure on YYY, it is countably additive:

μ2(B)=∑i∈I(x)μ(Bi)  ⟹  IA(x)μ2(B)=∑i≥1IAi(x)⋅μ2(B). \mu_2 (B) = \sum_{i \in I(x) } \mu(B_i ) \implies \mathbb{I}_A (x) \mu_2(B) = \sum_{i \ge 1} \mathbb{I}_{ A_i } (x) \cdot \mu_2 (B). μ2​(B)=i∈I(x)∑​μ(Bi​)⟹IA​(x)μ2​(B)=i≥1∑​IAi​​(x)⋅μ2​(B).

By monotone convergence theorem,

∫XIA(x)μ2(B) d μ1=∑i≥1∫XIAi(x)⋅μ2(B)d μ1, \int_X \mathbb{I}_A(x) \mu_2(B) \, d\, \mu_1 = \sum_{i \ge 1} \int_X \mathbb{I}_{ A_i } (x) \cdot \mu_2 (B) d\, \mu_1, ∫X​IA​(x)μ2​(B)dμ1​=i≥1∑​∫X​IAi​​(x)⋅μ2​(B)dμ1​,

which is

μ1(A)⋅μ2(B)=∑i≥1μ1(Ai)⋅μ2(Bi). \mu_1 (A) \cdot \mu_2 (B) = \sum_{i \ge 1} \mu_1 (A_i) \cdot \mu_2 (B_i). μ1​(A)⋅μ2​(B)=i≥1∑​μ1​(Ai​)⋅μ2​(Bi​).

□\square□

Theorem. μ\muμ has a unique extension μˉ\bar \muμˉ​ on σ(S)\sigma( \mathcal{S} )σ(S), the σ\sigmaσ-field generated by S\mathcal{S}S.

Proof. Note that S\mathcal{S}S is a semialgebra and μ\muμ is a σ\sigmaσ-finite measure.
Applying
Caratheodory’s Extension Theorem
directly finishes the proof.

□\square□

Fubini’s Theorem

Let {ai:i∈N}\begin{Bmatrix} a_i : i \in \mathbb{N} \end{Bmatrix}{ai​:i∈N​} be a countably sequence of numbers.
Then the series converges to the same limit under permutation, if

  1. ai≥0,∀i∈Na_i \ge 0, \forall i \in \mathbb{N}ai​≥0,∀i∈N. Note that ∑i≥1ai\sum_{i \ge 1} a_i∑i≥1​ai​ can equal ∞\infty∞.

  2. ∑i≥1∣ai∣<∞\sum_{i \ge 1} | a_i | < \infty∑i≥1​∣ai​∣<∞.

Integration is a generalization of discrete sum.
Given a measure space (Ω,σ(S),μˉ)(\Omega, \sigma( \mathcal{S} ), \bar \mu)(Ω,σ(S),μˉ​), and a measure function fff, the integral of fff exists, if

  1. f≥0f \ge 0f≥0;
  2. Or ∫∣f∣d μˉ<∞\int |f| d\, \bar \mu < \infty∫∣f∣dμˉ​<∞.

In case that (Ω,σ(S),μˉ)(\Omega, \sigma( \mathcal{S} ), \bar \mu)(Ω,σ(S),μˉ​) is a produce measure space, the Fubini’s theorem states that if the double integral exists, it can be computed by iterated integrals.

Theorem (Fubini’s Theorem). If f≥0f \ge 0f≥0 or ∫∣f∣d μˉ<∞\int |f| d\, \bar \mu < \infty∫∣f∣dμˉ​<∞, then there exists A∈F1A \in \mathcal{F}_1A∈F1​, B∈F2B \in \mathcal{F}_2B∈F2​, s.t., μ1(A)=μ2(B)=0\mu_1 (A) = \mu_2 (B) = 0μ1​(A)=μ2​(B)=0, and

∫X−A∫Yf(x,y)d μ2 d μ1=∫Ωf(x,y)d μˉ=∫Y−B∫Xf(x,y)d μ1 d μ2. \int_{X - A} \int_Y f(x, y) d\, \mu_2 \, d\, \mu_1 = \int_{\Omega } f(x, y) d\, \bar \mu = \int_{Y - B} \int_X f(x, y) d\, \mu_1 \, d\, \mu_2. ∫X−A​∫Y​f(x,y)dμ2​dμ1​=∫Ω​f(x,y)dμˉ​=∫Y−B​∫X​f(x,y)dμ1​dμ2​.

Remark. For the case concerning f≥0f \ge 0f≥0, we have A=B=∅A = B = \emptysetA=B=∅, and the Theorem is called Tonelli’s theorem.

Comparison with Discrete Sum

Let X=Y=NX = Y = \mathbb{N}X=Y=N, and μ1=μ2\mu_1 = \mu_2μ1​=μ2​ be counting measures.
Let {ai,j:i,j∈N}\begin{Bmatrix} a_{i,j} : i, j \in \mathbb{N} \end{Bmatrix}{ai,j​:i,j∈N​} be a sequency of numbers and define f(i,j)=ai,jf(i, j) = a_{i,j}f(i,j)=ai,j​.
Denote

E1≐{(i,j)∈N×N:ai,j≥0},E2≐{(i,j)∈N×N:ai,j<0}. E_1 \doteq \begin{Bmatrix} (i, j) \in \mathbb{N} \times \mathbb{N} : a_{i,j} \ge 0 \end{Bmatrix}, \\ E_2 \doteq \begin{Bmatrix} (i, j) \in \mathbb{N} \times \mathbb{N} : a_{i,j} < 0 \end{Bmatrix}. E1​≐{(i,j)∈N×N:ai,j​≥0​},E2​≐{(i,j)∈N×N:ai,j​<0​}.

By definition of integration,
∫Ωf(x,y) d μˉ\int_\Omega f(x, y) \, d\, \bar \mu∫Ω​f(x,y)dμˉ​ exists if

  1. Either f≥0f \ge 0f≥0. In this case

    ∫Ωf(x,y) d μˉ=sup⁡{∑(i,j)∈Sai,j:S⊆N×N∣S∣<∞}, \int_\Omega f(x, y) \, d\, \bar \mu = \sup \begin{Bmatrix} \sum_{ ( i,j ) \in S } a_{i,j} : \begin{array}{l} S \subseteq \mathbb{N} \times \mathbb{N} \\ |S| < \infty \end{array} \end{Bmatrix}, ∫Ω​f(x,y)dμˉ​=sup{∑(i,j)∈S​ai,j​:S⊆N×N∣S∣<∞​​},

  2. Or ∫Ω∣f(x,y)∣ d μˉ<∞\int_\Omega | f(x, y) | \, d\, \bar \mu < \infty∫Ω​∣f(x,y)∣dμˉ​<∞. In this case,

    ∫Ωf(x,y) d μˉ=∫Ωf+ d μˉ−∫Ωf− d μˉ=sup⁡{∑(i,j)∈Sai,j: S⊆E1∣S∣<∞}−sup⁡{∑(i,j)∈Sai,j: S⊆E2∣S∣<∞}. \begin{aligned} &\int_\Omega f(x, y) \, d\, \bar \mu = \int_\Omega f_+ \, d\, \bar \mu - \int_\Omega f_- \, d\, \bar \mu \\ &= \sup \begin{Bmatrix} \sum_{ ( i,j ) \in S } a_{i,j}: \, \begin{matrix} S \subseteq E_1 \\ |S| < \infty \end{matrix} \end{Bmatrix} - \sup \begin{Bmatrix} \sum_{ ( i,j ) \in S } a_{i,j}: \, \begin{matrix} S \subseteq E_2 \\ |S| < \infty \end{matrix} \end{Bmatrix} . \end{aligned} ​∫Ω​f(x,y)dμˉ​=∫Ω​f+​dμˉ​−∫Ω​f−​dμˉ​=sup{∑(i,j)∈S​ai,j​:S⊆E1​∣S∣<∞​​}−sup{∑(i,j)∈S​ai,j​:S⊆E2​∣S∣<∞​​}.​

In the former case, the summation of elements in a chosen set SSS grows in one direction. While in the later, the summation converges absolutely.

When ∫Ωf(x,y) d μˉ\int_\Omega f(x, y) \, d\, \bar \mu∫Ω​f(x,y)dμˉ​ exists, the following iterated integrals exist:

∫X∫Yf(x,y)d μ2 d μ1=∑i≥1∑j≥1ai,j,∫Y∫Xf(x,y)d μ1 d μ2=∑j≥1∑i≥1ai,j. \int_X \int_Y f(x, y) d\, \mu_2 \, d\, \mu_1 = \sum_{i \ge 1} \sum_{j \ge 1} a_{i,j}, \\ \int_Y \int_X f(x, y) d\, \mu_1 \, d\, \mu_2 = \sum_{j \ge 1} \sum_{i \ge 1} a_{i,j}. ∫X​∫Y​f(x,y)dμ2​dμ1​=i≥1∑​j≥1∑​ai,j​,∫Y​∫X​f(x,y)dμ1​dμ2​=j≥1∑​i≥1∑​ai,j​.

Further, their values are equal.

□\square□

Proof of Fubini’s Theorem

By symmetry, it suffices to prove that

∫X∫Yf(x,y)d μ2 d μ1=∫Ωf(x,y)d μˉ. \int_X \int_Y f(x, y) d\, \mu_2 \, d\, \mu_1 = \int_{\Omega } f(x, y) d\, \bar \mu. ∫X​∫Y​f(x,y)dμ2​dμ1​=∫Ω​f(x,y)dμˉ​.

Sketch of the Proof

Before proving that the iterated integral equals the double integral, we need to make sure that the first iterated integral is well-defined.
Specifically,

  • When xxx is fixed, the function fx:Y→Rf_x : Y \rightarrow \mathbb{R}fx​:Y→R defined by fx(y)≐f(x,y)f_x(y) \doteq f(x, y)fx​(y)≐f(x,y) is F2\mathcal{F}_2F2​ measurable, and the integral ∫Yf(x,y) d μ2\int_Y f(x, y) \, d\, \mu_2∫Y​f(x,y)dμ2​ exists.

  • There is F1\mathcal{F}_1F1​ measurable function g:X→Rg : X \rightarrow \mathbb{R}g:X→R such that g(x)=∫Yf(x,y) d μ2g(x) = \int_Y f(x, y) \, d\, \mu_2g(x)=∫Y​f(x,y)dμ2​ almost everywhere.

We will first establish the theorem for indicator functions IE\mathbb{I}_EIE​ for sets E∈σ(S)E \in \sigma( \mathcal{S} )E∈σ(S), which serve as basic building blocks for extending the theorem for more general functions.

Lemma. Given E∈σ(S)E \in \sigma( \mathcal{S} )E∈σ(S), let IE\mathbb{I}_EIE​ be the indicator for (x,y)∈E(x, y) \in E(x,y)∈E. Then

  1. For each x∈Xx \in Xx∈X, the function fx(y)≐IE(x,y)f_x(y) \doteq \mathbb{I}_E (x, y)fx​(y)≐IE​(x,y) is F2\mathcal{F}_2F2​ measurable.

  2. The function g(x)≐∫YIE(x,y)d μ2g(x) \doteq \int_Y \mathbb{I}_E (x, y) d\, \mu_2g(x)≐∫Y​IE​(x,y)dμ2​ is F1\mathcal{F}_1F1​ measurable.

  3. ∫X∫YIE(x,y)d μ2 d μ1=∫ΩIE(x,y)d μˉ. \int_X \int_Y \mathbb{I}_E (x, y) d\, \mu_2 \, d\, \mu_1 = \int_{\Omega } \mathbb{I}_E (x, y) d\, \bar \mu. ∫X​∫Y​IE​(x,y)dμ2​dμ1​=∫Ω​IE​(x,y)dμˉ​.

The proof of the lemma is deferred to the end of the article.

Proof of the Theorem

For now, we apply it to prove Theorem for the following three increasingly more general cases.

Case One. fff is a simple function on (X×Y,σ(S))(X \times Y, \sigma(\mathcal{S}))(X×Y,σ(S)).

Case Two. f≥0f \ge 0f≥0 and is σ(S)\sigma(\mathcal{S})σ(S) measurable.

Case Three. fff is measurable and integrable.

Remark: this follows exactly the same order with which we define Lebesgue integrals.

Proof.

Case 1. Suppose that f(x,y)=∑i∈[n]ci⋅IEi(x,y)f(x, y) = \sum_{i \in [n]} c_i \cdot \mathbb{I}_{E_i} (x, y)f(x,y)=∑i∈[n]​ci​⋅IEi​​(x,y) is a simple function on (X×Y,σ(S))(X \times Y, \sigma(\mathcal{S}))(X×Y,σ(S)).

  1. For fixed x∈Xx \in Xx∈X, according the lemma, the functions fx(i)(y)≐IEi(x,y),i∈[n]f_x^{ (i) } (y) \doteq \mathbb{I}_{E_i} (x, y), i \in [n]fx(i)​(y)≐IEi​​(x,y),i∈[n] are F2\mathcal{F}_2F2​ measurable.
    It follows that function fx(y)=∑i∈[n]ci⋅fx(i)(y)f_x (y) = \sum_{i \in [n]} c_i \cdot f_x^{ (i) } (y)fx​(y)=∑i∈[n]​ci​⋅fx(i)​(y) is F2\mathcal{F}_2F2​ measurable.

  2. Since g(i)(x)≐∫YIEi(x,y)d μ2g^{(i)} (x) \doteq \int_Y \mathbb{I}_{E_i} (x, y) d\, \mu_2g(i)(x)≐∫Y​IEi​​(x,y)dμ2​ is F1\mathcal{F}_1F1​ measurable, so is the function

g(x)=∫Yfx(y)d μ2=∑i∈[n]ci⋅∫YIEi(x,y)d μ2 g(x) = \int_Y f_x(y) d\, \mu_2 = \sum_{i \in [n]} c_i \cdot \int_Y \mathbb{I}_{E_i} (x, y) d\, \mu_2 g(x)=∫Y​fx​(y)dμ2​=i∈[n]∑​ci​⋅∫Y​IEi​​(x,y)dμ2​

  1. Since ∫X∫YIEi(x,y)d μ2 d μ1=∫ΩIEi(x,y)d μˉ\int_X \int_Y \mathbb{I}_{E_i} (x, y) d\, \mu_2 \, d\, \mu_1 = \int_{\Omega } \mathbb{I}_{E_i} (x, y) d\, \bar \mu∫X​∫Y​IEi​​(x,y)dμ2​dμ1​=∫Ω​IEi​​(x,y)dμˉ​,

∫X∫Yf(x,y)d μ2 d μ1=∑i∈[n]ci⋅∫X∫YIEi(x,y)d μ2 d μ1=∑i∈[n]ci⋅∫ΩIEi(x,y)d μˉ=∫Ω∑i∈[n]ci⋅IEi(x,y)d μˉ=∫Ωf(x,y)d μˉ. \begin{aligned} \int_X \int_Y f(x, y) d\, \mu_2 \, d\, \mu_1 &= \sum_{i \in [n]} c_i \cdot \int_X \int_Y \mathbb{I}_{E_i} (x, y) d\, \mu_2 \, d\, \mu_1 \\ &= \sum_{i \in [n]} c_i \cdot \int_{\Omega } \mathbb{I}_{E_i} (x, y) d\, \bar \mu \\ &= \int_{\Omega } \sum_{i \in [n]} c_i \cdot\mathbb{I}_{E_i} (x, y) d\, \bar \mu \\ &= \int_{\Omega } f(x, y) d\, \bar \mu. \end{aligned} ∫X​∫Y​f(x,y)dμ2​dμ1​​=i∈[n]∑​ci​⋅∫X​∫Y​IEi​​(x,y)dμ2​dμ1​=i∈[n]∑​ci​⋅∫Ω​IEi​​(x,y)dμˉ​=∫Ω​i∈[n]∑​ci​⋅IEi​​(x,y)dμˉ​=∫Ω​f(x,y)dμˉ​.​

Case Two. Suppose that f≥0f \ge 0f≥0 and is σ(S)\sigma(\mathcal{S})σ(S) measurable.
Then there exists simple, nonnegative functions f(n)↑ff^{ (n) } \uparrow ff(n)↑f.

  1. For fixed x∈Xx \in Xx∈X. The functions fx(n)(y)≐f(n)(x,y)↑fx(y)f_x^{ (n) } (y) \doteq f^{ (n) } (x, y) \uparrow f_x(y)fx(n)​(y)≐f(n)(x,y)↑fx​(y). Since they are F2\mathcal{F}_2F2​ measurable, so is fx(y)≐f(x,y)f_x (y) \doteq f(x, y)fx​(y)≐f(x,y).

  2. Let g(n)(x)≐∫Yf(n)(x,y)d μ2g^{(n)} (x) \doteq \int_Y f^{ (n) } (x, y) d\, \mu_2g(n)(x)≐∫Y​f(n)(x,y)dμ2​.
    Since 0≤fx(n)(y)↑fx(y)0 \le f_x^{ (n) } (y) \uparrow f_x(y)0≤fx(n)​(y)↑fx​(y), by monotone convergence theorem:

    g(x)=∫Yfx(y)d μ2=lim⁡n∫Yf(n)(x,y)d μ2=lim⁡ng(n)(x) g(x) = \int_Y f_x(y) d\, \mu_2 = \lim_n \int_Y f^{ (n) } (x, y) d\, \mu_2 = \lim_n g^{(n)} (x) g(x)=∫Y​fx​(y)dμ2​=nlim​∫Y​f(n)(x,y)dμ2​=nlim​g(n)(x)

    It follows that g(n)(x)↑g(x)g^{(n)} (x) \uparrow g(x)g(n)(x)↑g(x).
    Since they are F1\mathcal{F}_1F1​ measurable, so is g(x)g(x)g(x).

  3. Since ∫Yf(n)(x,y)d μ2↑∫Yf(x,y)d μ2 \int_Y f^{ (n) } (x, y) d\, \mu_2 \uparrow \int_Y f(x, y) d\, \mu_2 \,∫Y​f(n)(x,y)dμ2​↑∫Y​f(x,y)dμ2​, ∫X∫Yf(n)(x,y)d μ2 d μ1=∫Ωf(n)(x,y)d μˉ \int_X \int_Y f^{ (n) } (x, y) d\, \mu_2 \, d\, \mu_1 = \int_{\Omega } f^{ (n) } (x, y) d\, \bar \mu \,∫X​∫Y​f(n)(x,y)dμ2​dμ1​=∫Ω​f(n)(x,y)dμˉ​, and f(n)(x,y)↑f(x,y)f^{(n)} (x, y) \uparrow f(x, y)f(n)(x,y)↑f(x,y), by monotone convergence theorem,

∫X∫Yf(x,y)d μ2 d μ1=lim⁡n∫X∫Yf(n)(x,y)d μ2 d μ1=lim⁡n∫Ωf(n)(x,y)d μˉ=∫Ωlim⁡nf(n)(x,y)d μˉ=∫Ωf(x,y)d μˉ. \begin{aligned} \int_X \int_Y f(x, y) d\, \mu_2 \, d\, \mu_1 &= \lim_n \int_X \int_Y f^{ (n) } (x, y) d\, \mu_2 \, d\, \mu_1 \\ &= \lim_n \int_{\Omega } f^{ (n) } (x, y) d\, \bar \mu \\ &= \int_{\Omega } \lim_n f^{ (n) } (x, y) d\, \bar \mu \\ &= \int_{\Omega } f (x, y) d\, \bar \mu. \end{aligned} ∫X​∫Y​f(x,y)dμ2​dμ1​​=nlim​∫X​∫Y​f(n)(x,y)dμ2​dμ1​=nlim​∫Ω​f(n)(x,y)dμˉ​=∫Ω​nlim​f(n)(x,y)dμˉ​=∫Ω​f(x,y)dμˉ​.​

Case Three. Suppose that f(x,y)f(x, y)f(x,y) is a measurable and integrable function on X×YX \times YX×Y, i.e., ∫Ω∣f(x,y)∣d μˉ<∞\int_{\Omega } |f(x, y)| d\, \bar \mu < \infty∫Ω​∣f(x,y)∣dμˉ​<∞.

Proof of the Lemma

Lemma. Given E∈σ(S)E \in \sigma( \mathcal{S} )E∈σ(S), let IE\mathbb{I}_EIE​ be the indicator for (x,y)∈E(x, y) \in E(x,y)∈E. Then

  2. The function g(x)≐∫YIE(x,y)d μ2g(x) \doteq \int_Y \mathbb{I}_E (x, y) d\, \mu_2g(x)≐∫Y​IE​(x,y)dμ2​ is F1\mathcal{F}_1F1​ measurable.

  3. ∫X∫YIE(x,y)d μ2 d μ1=∫ΩIE(x,y)d μˉ. \int_X \int_Y \mathbb{I}_E (x, y) d\, \mu_2 \, d\, \mu_1 = \int_{\Omega } \mathbb{I}_E (x, y) d\, \bar \mu. ∫X​∫Y​IE​(x,y)dμ2​dμ1​=∫Ω​IE​(x,y)dμˉ​.

There are various ways to prove this lemma.
We present two proofs here.

Proof One

Since XXX and YYY are both σ\sigmaσ-finite, there exists Ak∈F1,μ1(Ak)<∞,∀n∈N+A_k \in \mathcal{F}_1, \mu_1(A_k) < \infty, \forall n \in \mathbb{N}^+Ak​∈F1​,μ1​(Ak​)<∞,∀n∈N+, s.t., Ak↑XA_k \uparrow XAk​↑X, and Bk∈F2,μ2(Bk)<∞,∀n∈N+B_k \in \mathcal{F}_2, \mu_2(B_k) < \infty, \forall n \in \mathbb{N}^+Bk​∈F2​,μ2​(Bk​)<∞,∀n∈N+, s.t., Bk↑YB_k \uparrow YBk​↑Y.
It follows that Ωk≐Ak×Bk↑Ω\Omega_k \doteq A_k \times B_k \uparrow \OmegaΩk​≐Ak​×Bk​↑Ω, and that μ(Ωk)<∞\mu(\Omega_k) < \inftyμ(Ωk​)<∞.

Define

Lk≐{E∈σ(S):E∩Ωk  satisfies the conditions in the Lemma }. \mathcal{L}_k \doteq \{ E \in \sigma(\mathcal{S}) : E \cap \Omega_k \, \text{ satisfies the conditions in the Lemma } \}. Lk​≐{E∈σ(S):E∩Ωk​ satisfies the conditions in the Lemma }.

Claim. If Lk=σ(S)\mathcal{L}_k = \sigma(\mathcal{S})Lk​=σ(S),
then the lemma holds.

The proof relies on the following fact.

The proof consists of two steps:

  3. Since 0≤μ2(Y)−∫Yf(n)(x,y)d μ2↑μ2(Y)−∫Yf(x,y)d μ2 0 \le \mu_2(Y) - \int_Y f^{ (n) } (x, y) d\, \mu_2 \uparrow \mu_2(Y) - \int_Y f(x, y) d\, \mu_2 \,0≤μ2​(Y)−∫Y​f(n)(x,y)dμ2​↑μ2​(Y)−∫Y​f(x,y)dμ2​, ∫X∫Yf(n)(x,y)d μ2 d μ1=∫Ωf(n)(x,y)d μˉ \int_X \int_Y f^{ (n) } (x, y) d\, \mu_2 \, d\, \mu_1 = \int_{\Omega } f^{ (n) } (x, y) d\, \bar \mu \,∫X​∫Y​f(n)(x,y)dμ2​dμ1​=∫Ω​f(n)(x,y)dμˉ​, and 0≤1−f(n)(x,y)↑1−f(x,y)0 \le 1 - f^{(n)} (x, y) \uparrow 1 - f(x, y)0≤1−f(n)(x,y)↑1−f(x,y), by monotone convergence theorem,

    μ(Ω)−∫X∫Yf(x,y)d μ2 d μ1=∫X(μ2(Y)−∫Yf(x,y)d μ2) d μ1=lim⁡n∫X(μ2(Y)−∫Yf(n)(x,y)d μ2) d μ1=μ(Ω)−lim⁡n∫Ωf(n)(x,y)d μˉ=lim⁡n∫Ω(1−f(n)(x,y))d μˉ=∫Ωlim⁡n(1−f(n)(x,y))d μˉ=μ(Ω)−∫Ωf(x,y)d μˉ. \begin{aligned} \mu(\Omega) - \int_X \int_Y f(x, y) d\, \mu_2 \, d\, \mu_1 &= \int_X \left( \mu_2(Y) - \int_Y f(x, y) d\, \mu_2 \right) \, d\, \mu_1 \\ &= \lim_n \int_X \left( \mu_2(Y) - \int_Y f^{ (n) } (x, y) d\, \mu_2 \right) \, d\, \mu_1 \\ &= \mu(\Omega) - \lim_n \int_{\Omega } f^{ (n) } (x, y) d\, \bar \mu \\ &= \lim_n \int_{\Omega } \left( 1 - f^{ (n) } (x, y) \right) d\, \bar \mu \\ &= \int_{\Omega } \lim_n \left(1 - f^{ (n) } (x, y) \right) d\, \bar \mu \\ &= \mu(\Omega) - \int_{\Omega } f (x, y) d\, \bar \mu. \end{aligned} μ(Ω)−∫X​∫Y​f(x,y)dμ2​dμ1​​=∫X​(μ2​(Y)−∫Y​f(x,y)dμ2​)dμ1​=nlim​∫X​(μ2​(Y)−∫Y​f(n)(x,y)dμ2​)dμ1​=μ(Ω)−nlim​∫Ω​f(n)(x,y)dμˉ​=nlim​∫Ω​(1−f(n)(x,y))dμˉ​=∫Ω​nlim​(1−f(n)(x,y))dμˉ​=μ(Ω)−∫Ω​f(x,y)dμˉ​.​

    Observing that μ(Ω)<∞\mu(\Omega) < \inftyμ(Ω)<∞ finishes the proof.

□\square□

Proof Two

Lemma. Given E∈σ(S)E \in \sigma( \mathcal{S} )E∈σ(S), let f(x,y)=IE(x,y)f(x, y) = \mathbb{I}_E (x, y)f(x,y)=IE​(x,y) be the indicator for (x,y)∈E(x, y) \in E(x,y)∈E. Then

  1. For each x∈Xx \in Xx∈X, the function fx(y)≐IE(x,y)f_x(y) \doteq \mathbb{I}_E (x, y)fx​(y)≐IE​(x,y) is F2\mathcal{F}_2F2​ measurable.

  2. The function g(x)≐∫YIE(x,y)d μ2g(x) \doteq \int_Y \mathbb{I}_E (x, y) d\, \mu_2g(x)≐∫Y​IE​(x,y)dμ2​ is F1\mathcal{F}_1F1​ measurable.

  3. ∫X∫YIE(x,y)d μ2 d μ1=∫ΩIE(x,y)d μˉ. \int_X \int_Y \mathbb{I}_E (x, y) d\, \mu_2 \, d\, \mu_1 = \int_{\Omega } \mathbb{I}_E (x, y) d\, \bar \mu. ∫X​∫Y​IE​(x,y)dμ2​dμ1​=∫Ω​IE​(x,y)dμˉ​.

Proof of (1).

Definition. Let Ex≐{y:(x,y)∈E}E_x \doteq \begin{Bmatrix} y : (x, y) \in E \end{Bmatrix}Ex​≐{y:(x,y)∈E​} be the cross-section at xxx.

It suffices to show that

Claim. For each x∈Xx \in Xx∈X and E∈σ(S)E \in \sigma(\mathcal{S})E∈σ(S), Ex∈F2E_x \in \mathcal{F}_2Ex​∈F2​.

Proof of the Claim.
Fix an x∈Xx \in Xx∈X.
Define the function Tx:Y→X×YT_x : Y \rightarrow X \times YTx​:Y→X×Y by Tx(y)≐(x,y).T_x (y) \doteq (x, y).Tx​(y)≐(x,y).
Then for each E=A×B∈SE = A \times B \in \mathcal{S}E=A×B∈S,

Tx−1(E)=Ex={B, if x∈A,∅, otherwise . T_x^{-1} (E) = E_x = \begin{cases} B, &\text{ if } x \in A, \\ \emptyset, & \text{ otherwise }. \end{cases} Tx−1​(E)=Ex​={B,∅,​ if x∈A, otherwise .​

Therefore Tx−1(E)=Ex∈F2T_x^{-1} (E) = E_x \in \mathcal{F}_2Tx−1​(E)=Ex​∈F2​.
Since S\mathcal{S}S generates σ(S)\sigma(\mathcal{S})σ(S), we conclude that TxT_xTx​ is measurable F2/σ(S)\mathcal{F}_2 / \sigma(\mathcal{S})F2​/σ(S).

□\square□

Proof of (2) and (3).

Define the set L⊆σ(S)\mathcal{L} \subseteq \sigma(\mathcal{S})L⊆σ(S) as the collection of EEE for which the condition (2) and (3) hold.

  1. Clearly it holds that S⊆L\mathcal{S} \subseteq \mathcal{L}S⊆L;
  2. We show that L\mathcal{L}L is a λ\lambdaλ system.

Since S\mathcal{S}S is a π\piπ system, via Dynkin’s π−λ\pi-\lambdaπ−λ theorem, L\mathcal{L}L is a σ\sigmaσ-algebra, and hence L=σ(S)\mathcal{L} = \sigma(\mathcal{S})L=σ(S).

We will now check that L\mathcal{L}L is a λ\lambdaλ-system.
With the same technique applied in previous proof, we can suppose without loss of generality that μ(Ω)<∞\mu(\Omega) < \inftyμ(Ω)<∞.

  1. Ω∈L\Omega \in \mathcal{L}Ω∈L.

  2. If E∈LE \in \mathcal{L}E∈L, then Eˉ∈L\bar E \in \mathcal{L}Eˉ∈L.
    First, observe that Eˉx=Ωx−Ex=B−Ex∈F2\bar E_x = \Omega_x - E_x = B - E_x \in \mathcal{F}_2Eˉx​=Ωx​−Ex​=B−Ex​∈F2​.
    Since μ2(B)<∞\mu_2(B) < \inftyμ2​(B)<∞,

    gEˉ(x)=μ2(Eˉx)=μ2(Ωx−Ex)=μ2(B)−μ2(Ex). g_{\bar E} (x) = \mu_2 ( \bar E_x ) = \mu_2 (\Omega_x - E_x) = \mu_2 (B) - \mu_2 (E_x). gEˉ​(x)=μ2​(Eˉx​)=μ2​(Ωx​−Ex​)=μ2​(B)−μ2​(Ex​).

    Since gE(x)=μ2(Ex)g_E(x) = \mu_2 (E_x)gE​(x)=μ2​(Ex​) is F1\mathcal{F}_1F1​ measurable, so is gEˉ(x)g_{\bar E}(x)gEˉ​(x).
    Integrating over xxx gives

    ∫Xμ2(Eˉx) d μ1=∫Xμ2(B) d μ1−∫Xμ2(Ex) d μ1=μ(Ω)−μ(E). \begin{aligned} \int_X \mu_2 ( \bar E_x ) \, d\, \mu_1 &= \int_X \mu_2 (B) \, d\, \mu_1 - \int_X \mu_2 (E_x) \, d\, \mu_1 \\ &= \mu (\Omega) - \mu(E). \end{aligned} ∫X​μ2​(Eˉx​)dμ1​​=∫X​μ2​(B)dμ1​−∫X​μ2​(Ex​)dμ1​=μ(Ω)−μ(E).​

    Since μ(Ω)<∞\mu(\Omega) < \inftyμ(Ω)<∞, we have μ(Eˉ)=μ(Ω)−μ(E)=∫Xμ2(Eˉx) d μ1\mu(\bar E) = \mu (\Omega) - \mu(E) = \int_X \mu_2 ( \bar E_x ) \, d\, \mu_1μ(Eˉ)=μ(Ω)−μ(E)=∫X​μ2​(Eˉx​)dμ1​.

  3. If En∈L,n∈N+E_n \in \mathcal{L}, n \in \mathbb{N}^+En​∈L,n∈N+ is a disjoint sequence of sets, then ∪n≥1En∈L\cup_{n \ge 1} E_n \in \mathcal{L}∪n≥1​En​∈L. Define gEn(x)≐μ2((En)x)g_{E_n} (x) \doteq \mu_2 ( (E_n)_x )gEn​​(x)≐μ2​((En​)x​).
    Then g(x)≐∑n≥1gEn(x)g(x) \doteq \sum_{n \ge 1} g_{E_n} (x)g(x)≐∑n≥1​gEn​​(x) is F1\mathcal{F}_1F1​ measurable, since g=sup⁡n≥1∑k∈[n]gEkg = \sup_{n \ge 1} \sum_{k \in [n]} g_{E_k}g=supn≥1​∑k∈[n]​gEk​​.
    By monotone convergence theorem and that μ\muμ is a measure, it holds that

    ∫Xg d μ1=∫X∑n≥1gEn d μ1=∑n≥1∫XgEn d μ1=∑n≥1μ(En)=μ(E). \int_X g \, d\, \mu_1 = \int_X \sum_{n \ge 1} g_{E_n} \, d\, \mu_1 = \sum_{n \ge 1} \int_X g_{E_n} \, d\, \mu_1 = \sum_{n \ge 1} \mu (E_n) = \mu (E). ∫X​gdμ1​=∫X​n≥1∑​gEn​​dμ1​=n≥1∑​∫X​gEn​​dμ1​=n≥1∑​μ(En​)=μ(E).

    Therefore, E∈LE \in \mathcal{L}E∈L.

□\square□

Remarks

Given a function f(x,y)f(x, y)f(x,y), there is an easier way to prove that it is measurable F2/B\mathcal{F}_2 / \mathcal{B}F2​/B when xxx is fixed, without approximating it by simple functions.
However, to prove the measurability of ∫Yf(x,y) dμ2\int_Y f(x, y) \, d \mu_2∫Y​f(x,y)dμ2​ (as a function of xxx), we still need to write it as the limit of simple functions.

Lemma. Let f:X×Y→Rf: X \times Y \rightarrow \mathbb{R}f:X×Y→R be measurable σ(S)/B\sigma(\mathcal{S}) / \mathcal{B}σ(S)/B.
For each x∈Xx \in Xx∈X, the function fx:Y→Rf_x : Y \rightarrow \mathbb{R}fx​:Y→R defined by fx(y)=f(x,y)f_x(y) = f(x, y)fx​(y)=f(x,y) is measurable F2/B\mathcal{F}_2 / \mathcal{B}F2​/B.

Proof.
Note that fx=f∘Txf_x = f \circ T_xfx​=f∘Tx​.
Since TxT_xTx​ is measurable F2/σ(S)\mathcal{F}_2 / \sigma(\mathcal{S})F2​/σ(S) and fff is measurable σ(S)/B\sigma(\mathcal{S}) / \mathcal{B}σ(S)/B, it follows that fxf_xfx​ is measurable F2/B\mathcal{F}_2 / \mathcal{B}F2​/B.

Or, specifically, for each Borel set W∈BW \in \mathcal{B}W∈B, since fff is measurable σ(S)/B\sigma(\mathcal{S}) / \mathcal{B}σ(S)/B,

E=f−1(W)={(x,y):f(x,y)∈W}∈σ(S). E = f^{-1} (W) = \{ (x, y) : f(x, y) \in W \} \in \sigma (\mathcal{S}). E=f−1(W)={(x,y):f(x,y)∈W}∈σ(S).

Then

fx−1(W)={y:f(x,y)∈W}=Ex∈F2. f_x^{-1} (W) = \{ y : f(x, y) \in W \} = E_x \in \mathcal{F}_2. fx−1​(W)={y:f(x,y)∈W}=Ex​∈F2​.

□\square□

For completeness, we include a proof for the following fact.
Observe that the technique applied here is similar to the one used in the proof for π\piπ-λ\lambdaλ theorem.

Fact. If S~\tilde{S}S~ is an algebra, then the monotone class M(S~)\mathcal{M}(\tilde{S})M(S~) generated by S~\tilde{S}S~ equals σ(S~)\sigma(\tilde{S})σ(S~).

Proof.
It is trivial to see M(S~)⊆σ(S~)\mathcal{M}(\tilde{S}) \subseteq \sigma(\tilde{S})M(S~)⊆σ(S~).

We prove the other direction by showing that M(S~)\mathcal{M}(\tilde{S})M(S~) is an algebra.
The proof consists of two steps:

  1. For each E∈S~E \in \tilde{S}E∈S~, we prove that

    R(E)≐{F∈M(S~):E∪F,F−E,E−F∈M(S~)}=M(S~). \mathcal{R}(E) \doteq \left\{ F \in \mathcal{M}(\tilde{S}) : E \cup F, F - E, E - F \in \mathcal{M}(\tilde{S}) \right\} = \mathcal{M}(\tilde{S}). R(E)≐{F∈M(S~):E∪F,F−E,E−F∈M(S~)}=M(S~).

    Clearly S~⊆R(E)\tilde{S} \subseteq \mathcal{R}(E)S~⊆R(E).
    We prove that R(E)\mathcal{R}(E)R(E) is a monotone class.
    Suppose that Fn→FF_n \rightarrow FFn​→F is an increasing or decreasing sequence.
    Then E∪Fn,Fn−E,E−FnE \cup F_n, F_n - E, E - F_nE∪Fn​,Fn​−E,E−Fn​ are also increasing or decreasing sequences.
    Therefore, E∪F,F−E,E−F∈R(E)E \cup F, F - E, E - F \in \mathcal{R}(E)E∪F,F−E,E−F∈R(E).

  2. For each E∈M(S~)E \in \mathcal{M}(\tilde{S})E∈M(S~), we prove that

    R(E)≐{F∈M(S~):E∪F,F−E,E−F∈M(S~)}=M(S~). \mathcal{R}(E) \doteq \left\{ F \in \mathcal{M}(\tilde{S}) : E \cup F, F - E, E - F \in \mathcal{M}(\tilde{S}) \right\} = \mathcal{M}(\tilde{S}). R(E)≐{F∈M(S~):E∪F,F−E,E−F∈M(S~)}=M(S~).

    If F∈S~F \in \tilde{S}F∈S~, then the previous claim E∈R(F)E \in \mathcal{R}(F)E∈R(F).
    Therefore, F∈R(E)F \in \mathcal{R}(E)F∈R(E).
    Following similar vein, we can also prove that R(E)\mathcal{R}(E)R(E) is a monotone class.

□\square□

Jensen's Inequality

Posted on 2021-06-25 Edited on 2024-03-11

Let (Ω,F,μ)(\Omega, \mathcal{F}, \mu)(Ω,F,μ) be a probability space.
Let X:Ω→RX: \Omega \rightarrow \mathbb{R}X:Ω→R be a random variable, s.t., X−1(B)∈FX^{-1}(B) \in \mathcal{F}X−1(B)∈F, ∀B∈R\forall B \in \mathcal{R}∀B∈R, where R\mathcal{R}R is the collection of Borel sets in R\mathbb{R}R.

Suppose that φ\varphiφ is a convex function defined on the interval I=[a,b]I = [a, b]I=[a,b], and that X(Ω)⊂IX(\Omega) \subset IX(Ω)⊂I.

Assume that both XXX and φ∘X\varphi \circ Xφ∘X are integrable.

Theorem. (Jensen’s Inequality)

φ(E[X])=φ(∫X d μ)≤∫φ(X) d μ=E[φ(X)]. \varphi (\mathbb{E}[ X ]) = \varphi \left( \int X \, d\, \mu \right) \le \int \varphi (X) \, d\, \mu = \mathbb{E}[ \varphi (X) ]. φ(E[X])=φ(∫Xdμ)≤∫φ(X)dμ=E[φ(X)].

Proof. Since X(Ω)⊂IX(\Omega) \subset IX(Ω)⊂I, by monotonicity of integration, it holds that

x∗≐E[X]=∫X d μ∈I. x^* \doteq \mathbb{E}[ X ] = \int X \, d\, \mu \in I. x∗≐E[X]=∫Xdμ∈I.

Case 1. Suppose that x∗∈(a,b)x^* \in (a, b)x∗∈(a,b).
As φ\varphiφ is convex, there exits a linear function h(x)=c(x−x∗)+φ(x∗)h(x) = c (x - x^*) + \varphi( x^*)h(x)=c(x−x∗)+φ(x∗) such that

  • φ(x)≥h(x)\varphi (x) \ge h(x)φ(x)≥h(x) for all x∈Ix \in Ix∈I.

Hence, by monotonicity of integration,

E[φ(X)]=∫φ(X) d μ≥∫c(X−x∗)+φ(x∗) d μ=φ(x∗)=φ(E[X]). \mathbb{E}[ \varphi (X) ] = \int \varphi (X) \, d\, \mu \ge \int c (X - x^*) + \varphi( x^*) \, d\, \mu = \varphi (x^*) = \varphi (\mathbb{E}[ X ]). E[φ(X)]=∫φ(X)dμ≥∫c(X−x∗)+φ(x∗)dμ=φ(x∗)=φ(E[X]).

Case 2. x∗=ax^* = ax∗=a (or bbb). Then

∫(X−a) d μ=0. \int \big( X - a \big) \, d\, \mu = 0. ∫(X−a)dμ=0.

It follows that X(ω)=aX(\omega) = aX(ω)=a a.e. ω∈Ω\omega \in \Omegaω∈Ω.
Clearly

φ(∫X d μ)=φ(a)=∫φ(X) d μ. \varphi \left( \int X \, d\, \mu \right) = \varphi (a) = \int \varphi (X) \, d\, \mu. φ(∫Xdμ)=φ(a)=∫φ(X)dμ.

□\square□

Example. Let φ(x)=−ln⁡x,∀x>0\varphi(x) = - \ln x, \forall x > 0φ(x)=−lnx,∀x>0.
Let x1,…,xn∈(0,∞)x_1, \ldots, x_n \in (0, \infty)x1​,…,xn​∈(0,∞).
Denote xˉ=(1/n)∑ixi\bar x = (1 / n) \sum_{i} x_ixˉ=(1/n)∑i​xi​.

φ(xˉ)≤1n∑i(−ln⁡xi). \varphi( \bar x ) \le \frac{1}{n} \sum_i (- \ln x_i ). φ(xˉ)≤n1​i∑​(−lnxi​).

Instead invoking the theorem directly, we apply the same technique to prove this again.
The claim is trivial if x1=…=xnx_1 = \ldots = x_nx1​=…=xn​.
Otherwise, consider the tangent line of φ(x)\varphi(x)φ(x) at xˉ\bar xxˉ:

h(x)=−1xˉ⋅(x−xˉ)−ln⁡xˉ. h(x) = - \frac{1}{ \bar x } \cdot (x - \bar x) - \ln \bar x. h(x)=−xˉ1​⋅(x−xˉ)−lnxˉ.

It holds that φ(xi)≥h(xi)\varphi(x_i) \ge h(x_i)φ(xi​)≥h(xi​), for all i∈[n]i \in [n]i∈[n].
Therefore,

1n∑ih(xi)≤1n∑i(−ln⁡xi). \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i} h(x_i) \le \frac{1}{n} \sum_i (- \ln x_i ). n1​i∑​h(xi​)≤n1​i∑​(−lnxi​).

On the other hand,

1n∑ih(xi)=−1xˉ⋅(1n∑ixi−xˉ)−ln⁡xˉ=−ln⁡xˉ. \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i} h(x_i) = - \frac{1}{ \bar x } \cdot \Big( \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i} x_i - \bar x \Big) - \ln \bar x = - \ln \bar x. n1​i∑​h(xi​)=−xˉ1​⋅(n1​i∑​xi​−xˉ)−lnxˉ=−lnxˉ.

Reference

[1] 实变函数论，第四章，例五，周民强.

Lebesgue Integral, Revisited.

Posted on 2021-06-19 Edited on 2022-02-07

Let (Ω,F,μ)(\Omega, \mathcal{F}, \mu)(Ω,F,μ) be measure space.
Further, suppose that μ\muμ is σ\sigmaσ-finite, i.e., there is a countable sequence {Sk}\{ S_k \}{Sk​} in F\mathcal{F}F, such that

  1. Sk↑ΩS_k \uparrow \OmegaSk​↑Ω.
  2. μ(Sk)<∞\mu (S_k) < \inftyμ(Sk​)<∞.

We study the integral, ∫f d μ\int f \, d\, \mu∫fdμ, of a measurable function fff. In what follows, we omit d μd\, \mudμ and abbreviate ∫f d μ\int f \, d\, \mu∫fdμ as ∫f\int f∫f.

Definition

Simple Function

Definition. For each A∈FA \in \mathcal{F}A∈F, define the indicator function 1A:Ω→R\mathbf{1}_A : \Omega \rightarrow \mathbb{R}1A​:Ω→R as

1A(ω)={1ω∈A 0ω∉A∀ω∈Ω. \mathbf{1}_A (\omega) = \begin{cases} 1 \quad \omega \in A\, \\ 0 \quad \omega \notin A \end{cases} \qquad \forall \omega \in \Omega. 1A​(ω)={1ω∈A0ω∈/A​∀ω∈Ω.

Definition. φ:Ω→R\varphi : \Omega \rightarrow \mathbb{R}φ:Ω→R is said to be a simple function if φ=∑i∈[n]ai1Ai\varphi = \sum_{i \in [n] } a_i \mathbf{1}_{ A_i }φ=∑i∈[n]​ai​1Ai​​, where Ai∈FA_i \in \mathcal{F}Ai​∈F are mutually disjoint.

We can assume that the {Ai}\{ A_i \}{Ai​} is a partition of Ω\OmegaΩ.
Otherwise, let An+1=Ω−A1−…−AnA_{n + 1} = \Omega - A_1 - \ldots - A_nAn+1​=Ω−A1​−…−An​ and an+1=0a_{n + 1} = 0an+1​=0.
Then A1,…,An+1A_1, \ldots, A_{n + 1}A1​,…,An+1​ is a partition of Ω\OmegaΩ, and

φ=∑i∈[n+1]ai1Ai. \varphi = \sum_{ i \in [n + 1] } a_i \mathbf{1}_{ A_i }. φ=i∈[n+1]∑​ai​1Ai​​.

The definition of integral of measurable functions consists of two steps.

Nonnegative Function

Bending the notation slightly, we say that fff is nonnegative, denoted as f≥0f \ge 0f≥0, if for all ω∈Ω\omega \in \Omegaω∈Ω, f(ω)≥0f(\omega) \ge 0f(ω)≥0.

Definition ♢\diamondsuit♢. Let f≥0f \ge 0f≥0 be measurable. Define

∫f≐sup⁡{∑i∈[n]aiμ(Ai):∑i∈[n]ai1Ai is simple,0≤∑i∈[n]ai1Ai≤f}. \int f \doteq \sup \left\{ \sum_{i \in [n] } a_i \mu(A_i): \begin{array}{l} \sum_{i \in [n] } a_i \mathbf{1}_{A_i} \text{ is simple}, \\ 0 \le \sum_{i \in [n] } a_i \mathbf{1}_{A_i} \le f \end{array} \right\}. ∫f≐sup⎩⎪⎨⎪⎧​i∈[n]∑​ai​μ(Ai​):∑i∈[n]​ai​1Ai​​ is simple,0≤∑i∈[n]​ai​1Ai​​≤f​⎭⎪⎬⎪⎫​.

It is possible that ∫f=∞\int f = \infty∫f=∞. We say that fff is integrable if ∫f<∞\int f < \infty∫f<∞.

For each nonnegative simple function φ=∑i∈[n]ai1Ai\varphi = \sum_{i \in [ n ] } a_i \mathbf{1}_{A_i}φ=∑i∈[n]​ai​1Ai​​,
define φk≐1Sk⋅φ=∑i∈[n]ai1Ai∩Sk\varphi_k \doteq \mathbf{1}_{S_k} \cdot \varphi = \sum_{i \in [n] } a_i \mathbf{1}_{A_i \cap S_k}φk​≐1Sk​​⋅φ=∑i∈[n]​ai​1Ai​∩Sk​​.
Note that φk\varphi_kφk​ has finite support and φk→φ\varphi_k \rightarrow \varphiφk​→φ.
By continuity of μ\muμ,

∑i∈[n]aiμ(Ai)=lim⁡k∑i∈[n]aiμ(Ai∩Sk). \sum_{i \in [n] } a_i \mu(A_i) = \lim_k \sum_{i \in [n] } a_i \mu(A_i \cap S_k). i∈[n]∑​ai​μ(Ai​)=klim​i∈[n]∑​ai​μ(Ai​∩Sk​).

Hence, the integral of fff has an equivalent definition.

Definition ♡\heartsuit♡. Let f≥0f \ge 0f≥0 be measurable. Define

∫f≐sup⁡{∑i∈[n]aiμ(Ai):∑i∈[n]ai1Ai is simple,Supp(∑i∈[n]ai1Ai)<∞,0≤∑i∈[n]ai1Ai≤f}. \int f \doteq \sup \left\{ \sum_{i \in [n] } a_i \mu(A_i): \begin{array}{ll} \sum_{i \in [n] } a_i \mathbf{1}_{A_i} \text{ is simple}, \\ \mathbb{Supp} \Big( \sum_{i \in [n] } a_i \mathbf{1}_{A_i} \Big) < \infty, \\ 0 \le \sum_{i \in [n] } a_i \mathbf{1}_{A_i} \le f \end{array} \right\}. ∫f≐sup⎩⎪⎪⎨⎪⎪⎧​i∈[n]∑​ai​μ(Ai​):∑i∈[n]​ai​1Ai​​ is simple,Supp(∑i∈[n]​ai​1Ai​​)<∞,0≤∑i∈[n]​ai​1Ai​​≤f​⎭⎪⎪⎬⎪⎪⎫​.

General Function

A general function f:Ω→Rf : \Omega \rightarrow \mathbb{R}f:Ω→R is said to be integrable if ∫∣f∣<∞\int |f| < \infty∫∣f∣<∞. Let f+=max⁡{f,0}f_+ = \max \{ f, 0\}f+​=max{f,0} and f−=max⁡{−f,0}f_- = \max \{ - f, 0 \}f−​=max{−f,0}. Then f=f+−f−f = f_+ - f_-f=f+​−f−​.

Definition ♣\clubsuit♣. Let fff be measurable. Define

∫f≐∫f+−∫f−. \int f \doteq \int f_+ - \int f_-. ∫f≐∫f+​−∫f−​.

Integration over a subset

Let f:Ω→Rf: \Omega \rightarrow \mathbb{R}f:Ω→R be measurable and E∈FE \in \mathcal{F}E∈F. Then

∫Ef≐∫f⋅1E. \int_E f \doteq \int f \cdot \mathbf{1}_{E}. ∫E​f≐∫f⋅1E​.

Remark: note that if fff is measurable and 1E\mathbf{1}_{E}1E​ is measurable, then f⋅1Ef \cdot \mathbf{1}_{E}f⋅1E​ is measurable.

Basic Properties

  1. Monotonicity. If f≥gf \ge gf≥g then ∫f≤∫g\int f \le \int g∫f≤∫g.

  2. Linearity. The integral is linear on the vector space of integral functions; in particular, ∀α,β∈R\forall \alpha, \beta \in \mathbb{R}∀α,β∈R, ∫α⋅f+β⋅g=α⋅∫f+β⋅∫g\int \alpha \cdot f + \beta \cdot g = \alpha \cdot \int f + \beta \cdot \int g∫α⋅f+β⋅g=α⋅∫f+β⋅∫g.

Monotonicity follows directly from the definition.
Establishing linearity is more fiddly and we leave it to the end of the article.
We proceed by assuming these two properties of integration.

Properties for Limits

Suppose that fn→ff_n \rightarrow ffn​→f a.e., when can we argue that

∫fn→∫f, \int f_n \rightarrow \int f, ∫fn​→∫f,

i.e., when the order of the limiting and the integration operations can be exchanged?

Intuitively, there are two kinds of convergence: the monotone ones and the bounded ones.

Monotone Convergence

Theorem (Monotone Convergence). If fn≥0f_n \ge 0fn​≥0 and fn↑ff_n \uparrow ffn​↑f, then

∫f=lim⁡n≥1∫fn. \int f = \lim_{n \ge 1} \int f_n. ∫f=n≥1lim​∫fn​.

Corollary 1. The integral is σ\sigmaσ-additive for nonnegative functions.

Corollary 2. If fn≥gf_n \ge gfn​≥g, where ggg is integrable, and fn↑ff_n \uparrow ffn​↑f, then

∫f=lim⁡n≥1∫fn. \int f = \lim_{n \ge 1} \int f_n. ∫f=n≥1lim​∫fn​.

Proof. As f≥fnf \ge f_nf≥fn​, by monotonicity of integration,
∫f≥∫fn\int f \ge \int f_n∫f≥∫fn​.
It follows that

∫f≥lim⁡n∫fn. \int f \ge \lim_{n} \int f_n. ∫f≥nlim​∫fn​.

It is left to prove the reverse direction of the inequality.
Let φ≐∑i∈[k]ai1Ai\varphi \doteq \sum_{i \in [k] } a_i \mathbf{1}_{ A_i }φ≐∑i∈[k]​ai​1Ai​​ be a simple function such that φ≤f\varphi \le fφ≤f.
Let c∈(0,1)c \in (0, 1)c∈(0,1), and define

En≐{ω∈Ω:fn(ω)≥c⋅φ(ω)}. E_n \doteq \{ \omega \in \Omega : f_n(\omega) \ge c \cdot \varphi (\omega) \}. En​≐{ω∈Ω:fn​(ω)≥c⋅φ(ω)}.

Exercise. Prove that En∈FE_n \in \mathcal{F}En​∈F.

Then

  1. c⋅φ⋅1En≤fnc \cdot \varphi \cdot 1_{E_n} \le f_nc⋅φ⋅1En​​≤fn​ is also a simple function.

  2. lim⁡nEn=Ω\lim_n E_n = \Omegalimn​En​=Ω, since fn↑ff_n \uparrow ffn​↑f.

By the definition of ∫fn\int f_n∫fn​, we have

∫c⋅φ⋅1En=∑i∈[k]c⋅ai⋅μ(Ai∩En)≤∫fn. \int c \cdot \varphi \cdot 1_{E_n} = \sum_{i \in [k] } c \cdot a_i \cdot \mu \big( A_i \cap E_n \big) \le \int f_n. ∫c⋅φ⋅1En​​=i∈[k]∑​c⋅ai​⋅μ(Ai​∩En​)≤∫fn​.

Taking limit of both side, and by continuity of μ\muμ, we get

lim⁡n∑i∈[k]c⋅ai⋅μ(Ai∩En)=c⋅∑i∈[k]ai⋅μ(Ak)=c⋅∫φ≤lim⁡n∫fn. \small \lim_n \sum_{i \in [k] } c \cdot a_i \cdot \mu \big( A_i \cap E_n \big) = c \cdot \sum_{i \in [k] } a_i \cdot \mu \big( A_k \big) = c \cdot \int \varphi \le \lim_n \int f_n. nlim​i∈[k]∑​c⋅ai​⋅μ(Ai​∩En​)=c⋅i∈[k]∑​ai​⋅μ(Ak​)=c⋅∫φ≤nlim​∫fn​.

Taking supremum over φ≤f\varphi \le fφ≤f and letting c→1c \rightarrow 1c→1, we get

∫f≤lim⁡n∫fn. \int f \le \lim_n \int f_n. ∫f≤nlim​∫fn​.

□\square□

Fatou’s Lemma

Theorem (Fatou’s Lemma). If fn≥0f_n \ge 0fn​≥0, then

∫lim inf⁡nfn≤lim inf⁡n∫fn. \int \liminf_n f_n \le \liminf_n \int f_n. ∫nliminf​fn​≤nliminf​∫fn​.

Corollary. If fn≤0f_n \le 0fn​≤0 and ggg is integrable, then

lim sup⁡n∫fn≤∫lim sup⁡nfn. \limsup_n \int f_n \le \int \limsup_n f_n . nlimsup​∫fn​≤∫nlimsup​fn​.

Corollary. If fn≥gf_n \ge gfn​≥g and ggg is integrable, then

∫lim inf⁡nfn≤lim inf⁡n∫fn. \int \liminf_n f_n \le \liminf_n \int f_n. ∫nliminf​fn​≤nliminf​∫fn​.

Corollary. If fn≤gf_n \le gfn​≤g and ggg is integrable, then

lim sup⁡n∫fn≤∫lim sup⁡nfn. \limsup_n \int f_n \le \int \limsup_n f_n . nlimsup​∫fn​≤∫nlimsup​fn​.

Proof. For all n≥1n \ge 1n≥1, define hn=inf⁡k≥nfkh_n = \inf_{k \ge n} f_khn​=infk≥n​fk​.
Since hn≤fnh_n \le f_nhn​≤fn​, by monotonicity of integration, ∫hn≤∫fn\int h_n \le \int f_n∫hn​≤∫fn​.
Taking lim inf⁡\liminfliminf of both side, we get

lim inf⁡n∫hn≤lim inf⁡n∫fn. \liminf_n \int h_n \le \liminf_n \int f_n. nliminf​∫hn​≤nliminf​∫fn​.

Then hn↑lim inf⁡nfnh_n \uparrow \liminf_n f_nhn​↑liminfn​fn​, by monotonicity of integration, ∫hn\int h_n∫hn​ is an increasing sequence.
It holds that lim inf⁡n∫hn=lim⁡n∫hn\liminf_n \int h_n = \lim_n \int h_nliminfn​∫hn​=limn​∫hn​.
It is left to prove

∫lim⁡nhn≤lim⁡n∫hn. \int \lim_n h_n \le \lim_n \int h_n. ∫nlim​hn​≤nlim​∫hn​.

This follows exactly from the Monotone Convergence theorem, or can be proven directly by using the same technique.

□\square□

Bounded Convergence

Theorem (Bounded Convergence). Let E∈FE \in \mathcal{F}E∈F with μ(E)<∞\mu(E) < \inftyμ(E)<∞. Let fnf_nfn​ be a sequence of functions supported on EEE with ∣fn∣≤M|f_n| \le M∣fn​∣≤M. Suppose that fn→ff_n \rightarrow ffn​→f point-wise. Then ∫fn→∫f\int f_n \rightarrow \int f∫fn​→∫f.

Proof. The proof relies on the lemma.

Lemma. If fn→ff_n \rightarrow ffn​→f point-wise, then fn→ff_n \rightarrow ffn​→f in measure.

Suppose fn→ff_n \rightarrow ffn​→f in measure. Let ϵ>0\epsilon > 0ϵ>0. Define An≐{ω∈Ω:∣fn−f∣>ϵ}⊂EA_n \doteq \{ \omega \in \Omega : |f_n - f| > \epsilon \} \subset EAn​≐{ω∈Ω:∣fn​−f∣>ϵ}⊂E. Then by linearity and monotonicity of integration,

∣∫fn−∫f∣=∣∫An(fn−f)+∫E−An(fn−f)∣≤∫An∣fn−f∣+∫E−An∣fn−f∣≤2⋅M⋅μ(An)+ϵ⋅μ(E). \begin{aligned} \left| \int f_n - \int f \right| &= \left| \int_{A_n} (f_n - f) + \int_{E - A_n} (f_n - f) \right| \\ &\le \int_{A_n} | f_n - f | + \int_{E - A_n} | f_n - f | \\ &\le 2 \cdot M \cdot \mu (A_n) + \epsilon \cdot \mu(E). \end{aligned} ∣∣∣∣∣​∫fn​−∫f∣∣∣∣∣​​=∣∣∣∣∣​∫An​​(fn​−f)+∫E−An​​(fn​−f)∣∣∣∣∣​≤∫An​​∣fn​−f∣+∫E−An​​∣fn​−f∣≤2⋅M⋅μ(An​)+ϵ⋅μ(E).​

Since μ(An)→0\mu(A_n) \rightarrow 0μ(An​)→0 and ϵ\epsilonϵ is arbitrary, this shows ∫fn→∫f\int f_n \rightarrow \int f∫fn​→∫f.

□\square□

Modulus of Integrability

Theorem (Modulus of integrability). Let f≥0f \ge 0f≥0 be integrable. Then for any ϵ>0\epsilon > 0ϵ>0 there is a δ>0\delta > 0δ>0 such that m(E)<δ  ⟹  ∫Ef<ϵm(E) < \delta \implies \int_E f < \epsilonm(E)<δ⟹∫E​f<ϵ.

Proof.
Define fn=min⁡(f,n)⋅1Snf_n = \min( f, n) \cdot \mathbb{1}_{S_n}fn​=min(f,n)⋅1Sn​​.
Then fn↑ff_n \uparrow ffn​↑f and by monotone convergence theorem, when nnn is large enough,

∫f−∫fn≤ϵ. \int f - \int f_n \le \epsilon. ∫f−∫fn​≤ϵ.

On the other hand, by monotonicity of integration, when δ<ϵ/n\delta < \epsilon / nδ<ϵ/n,

∫Efn≤∫En≤nδ<ϵ. \int_E f_n \le \int_E n \le n \delta < \epsilon. ∫E​fn​≤∫E​n≤nδ<ϵ.

Applying linearity and monotonicity of integration again,

∫Ef=∫E(f−fn)+∫Efn≤∫(f−fn)+nδ=2ϵ. \int_E f = \int_E (f - f_n) + \int_E f_n \le \int (f - f_n) + n \delta = 2 \epsilon. ∫E​f=∫E​(f−fn​)+∫E​fn​≤∫(f−fn​)+nδ=2ϵ.

□\square□

Dominated Convergence

Theorem (Dominated Convergence). If fn→f a.e.f_n \rightarrow f \, a.e.fn​→fa.e., ∣fn∣≤g|f_n| \le g∣fn​∣≤g for all nnn, and ggg is integrable, then ∫fn→∫f\int f_n \rightarrow \int f∫fn​→∫f.

Proof 1.

Step 1. ∃E∈F\exists E \in \mathcal{F}∃E∈F with μ(E)<∞\mu(E) < \inftyμ(E)<∞, such that ∫Ω−Eg≤ϵ\int_{\Omega - E} g \le \epsilon∫Ω−E​g≤ϵ.

Define gk=g⋅1Skg_k = g \cdot \mathbb{1}_{S_k}gk​=g⋅1Sk​​.
Then gk↑gg_k \uparrow ggk​↑g.
Using monotone convergence theorem and linearity of integration, there exists K≥0K \ge 0K≥0,

∫g−∫gK=∫Ω−SKg≤ϵ. \int g - \int g_K = \int_{\Omega - S_K} g \le \epsilon. ∫g−∫gK​=∫Ω−SK​​g≤ϵ.

Then we let E←SkE \leftarrow S_kE←Sk​.

Step 2.
Since fn→ff_n \rightarrow ffn​→f a.e., fn→ff_n \rightarrow ffn​→f in measure.
Define An≐{ω∈E:∣fn−f∣>ϵ}⊂EA_n \doteq \{ \omega \in E : |f_n - f| > \epsilon \} \subset EAn​≐{ω∈E:∣fn​−f∣>ϵ}⊂E.
Then μ(An)→0\mu(A_n) \rightarrow 0μ(An​)→0.

Finally, by linearity and monotonicity of integration,

∣∫fn−∫f∣≤∫An∣fn−f∣+∫E−An∣fn−f∣+∫Ω−E∣fn−f∣≤2∫Ang+ϵ⋅μ(E)+2⋅ϵ.\small \begin{array}{ll} \left| \int f_n - \int f \right| &\le \int_{A_n} | f_n - f | + \int_{E - A_n} | f_n - f | + \int_{\Omega - E} | f_n - f | \\ &\le 2 \int_{A_n} g + \epsilon \cdot \mu(E) + 2 \cdot \epsilon. \end{array} ∣∫fn​−∫f∣​≤∫An​​∣fn​−f∣+∫E−An​​∣fn​−f∣+∫Ω−E​∣fn​−f∣≤2∫An​​g+ϵ⋅μ(E)+2⋅ϵ.​

As μ(An)→0\mu(A_n) \rightarrow 0μ(An​)→0, ∫Ang→0\int_{A_n} g \rightarrow 0∫An​​g→0.
Since ϵ\epsilonϵ is arbitrary, this shows ∫fn→∫f\int f_n \rightarrow \int f∫fn​→∫f.

□\square□

Proof 2. There is a concise proof by Fatous’ lemma.

Let hn=2g−∣f−fn∣≥0h_n = 2g - |f - f_n| \ge 0hn​=2g−∣f−fn​∣≥0.
Using Fatous’ lemma,

∫lim⁡n(2g−∣f−fn∣)≤lim inf⁡n∫2g−∣f−fn∣. \int \lim_n \left( 2 g - |f - f_n | \right) \le \liminf_n \int 2 g - |f - f_n| . ∫nlim​(2g−∣f−fn​∣)≤nliminf​∫2g−∣f−fn​∣.

As ggg is integrable, we can subtract ∫g\int g∫g from both side and get

lim sup⁡n∫∣f−fn∣≤0. \limsup_n \int |f - f_n| \le 0. nlimsup​∫∣f−fn​∣≤0.

Therefore,

lim⁡n∫∣f−fn∣=0. \lim_n \int |f - f_n | = 0. nlim​∫∣f−fn​∣=0.

□\square□

Proof 3. Since ∣fn∣≤g|f_n| \le g∣fn​∣≤g, we have −g≤fn≤g- g \le f_n \le g−g≤fn​≤g.
As fn−(−g)=fn+g≥0f_n - (-g) = f_n + g \ge 0fn​−(−g)=fn​+g≥0, via Fatous’ lemma, we get

lim sup⁡∫fn=∫lim sup⁡fn=∫lim⁡fn=∫lim inf⁡fn≤lim inf⁡∫fn. \limsup \int f_n = \int \limsup f_n = \int \lim f_n = \int \liminf f_n \le \liminf \int f_n. limsup∫fn​=∫limsupfn​=∫limfn​=∫liminffn​≤liminf∫fn​.

□\square□

Linearity

It is difficult to prove linearity by the definitions of ♢\diamondsuit♢ or ♡\heartsuit♡. Hence, we introduce some equivalent definitions for integration, starting from simple functions.
These definitions also provide deeper intuitions.

Simple Functions

First, we prove that definition ♢\diamondsuit♢ has an equivalent one for nonnegative simple functions.

Theorem. Let φ≥0\varphi \ge 0φ≥0 be a simple function and ∑j∈[m]bj1Bj\sum_{j \in [m] } b_j \mathbf{1}_{B_j}∑j∈[m]​bj​1Bj​​ be one of its possible representations. Then it holds that

∫φ≐sup⁡{∑i∈[n]aiμ(Ai):∑i∈[n]ai1Ai is simple,0≤∑i∈[n]ai1Ai≤φ}=∑j∈[m]bjμ(Bj). \small \int \varphi \doteq \sup \left\{ \sum_{i \in [n] } a_i \mu(A_i): \begin{array}{l} \sum_{i \in [n] } a_i \mathbf{1}_{A_i} \text{ is simple}, \\ 0 \le \sum_{i \in [n] } a_i \mathbf{1}_{A_i} \le \varphi \end{array} \right\} = \sum_{j \in [m] } b_j \mu (B_j). ∫φ≐sup{i∈[n]∑​ai​μ(Ai​):∑i∈[n]​ai​1Ai​​ is simple,0≤∑i∈[n]​ai​1Ai​​≤φ​}=j∈[m]∑​bj​μ(Bj​).

Proof. By the definition of φ\varphiφ, clearly it holds that

∑j∈[m]bjμ(Bj)≤∫φ. \sum_{j \in [m] } b_j \mu (B_j) \le \int \varphi. j∈[m]∑​bj​μ(Bj​)≤∫φ.

To prove the reverse inequality, let ψ≐∑i∈[n]ai1Ai\psi \doteq \sum_{i \in [n] } a_i \mathbf{1}_{A_i}ψ≐∑i∈[n]​ai​1Ai​​ be a simple function, where Ai∈FA_i \in \mathcal{F}Ai​∈F are mutually disjoint.
Note that the {Bj}\{ B_j \}{Bj​} are also mutually disjoint.
If ψ≤φ\psi \le \varphiψ≤φ, it holds that for all i,ji, ji,j, either ai≤bja_i \le b_jai​≤bj​ or Ai∩Bj=∅A_i \cap B_j = \emptysetAi​∩Bj​=∅. Using that F\mathcal{F}F is a σ\sigmaσ-field and that μ\muμ is a measure on F\mathcal{F}F,

∑i∈[n]aiμ(Ai)=∑i∈[n],j∈[m]aiμ(Ai∩Bj)≤∑i∈[n],j∈[m]bjμ(Ai∩Bj)=∑j∈[m]bjμ(Bj). \begin{aligned} \sum_{i \in [n] } a_i \mu (A_i) &= \sum_{i \in [n], j \in [m] } a_i \mu (A_i \cap B_j ) \\ &\le \sum_{i \in [n], j \in [m] } b_j \mu (A_i \cap B_j ) = \sum_{j \in [m] } b_j \mu (B_j). \end{aligned} i∈[n]∑​ai​μ(Ai​)​=i∈[n],j∈[m]∑​ai​μ(Ai​∩Bj​)≤i∈[n],j∈[m]∑​bj​μ(Ai​∩Bj​)=j∈[m]∑​bj​μ(Bj​).​

Taking the supremum over all possible ψ≤φ\psi \le \varphiψ≤φ finishes the proof.

□\square□

Combined with definition ♣\clubsuit♣, we get

Corollary. Let φ\varphiφ be a simple function and ∑j∈[m]bj1Bj\sum_{j \in [m] } b_j \mathbf{1}_{B_j}∑j∈[m]​bj​1Bj​​ be one of its possible representations.

∫φ=∑j∈[m]bjμ(Bj). \small \int \varphi = \sum_{j \in [m] } b_j \mu (B_j). ∫φ=j∈[m]∑​bj​μ(Bj​).

We are ready to prove the linearity of integration for simple functions.

Linearity. The integral is linear on the vector space of simple functions.

Proof. If φ\varphiφ is a simple function, clearly ∫c⋅φ=c⋅∫φ\int c \cdot \varphi = c \cdot \int \varphi∫c⋅φ=c⋅∫φ for all c∈Rc \in \mathbb{R}c∈R. Let φ=∑i∈[n]ai1Ai\varphi = \sum_{i \in [n] } a_i \mathbf{1}_{ A_i }φ=∑i∈[n]​ai​1Ai​​ and ψ=∑j∈[m]bj1Bj\psi = \sum_{j \in [m] } b_j \mathbf{1}_{B_j}ψ=∑j∈[m]​bj​1Bj​​.
It is left to verify that ∫φ+ψ=∫φ+∫ψ\int \varphi + \psi = \int \varphi + \int \psi∫φ+ψ=∫φ+∫ψ.
As both the {Ai∈F:i∈[n]}\{ A_i \in \mathcal{F} : i \in [n] \}{Ai​∈F:i∈[n]} and {Bj∈F:j∈[m]}\{ B_j \in \mathcal{F} : j \in [m] \}{Bj​∈F:j∈[m]} are mutually disjoint, so are {Ai∩Bj∈F:i∈[n],j∈[m]}\{ A_i \cap B_j \in \mathcal{F} : i \in [n], j \in [m] \}{Ai​∩Bj​∈F:i∈[n],j∈[m]}. Then

φ+ψ=∑i∈[n],j∈[m](ai+bj)⋅1Ai∩Bj ∫φ+ψ=∑i∈[n],j∈[m](ai+bj)⋅μ(Ai∩Bj). \begin{aligned} \varphi + \psi &= \sum_{i \in [n], j \in [m] } (a_i + b_j) \cdot \mathbf{1}_{ A_i \cap B_j}\, \\ \int \varphi + \psi &= \sum_{i \in [n], j \in [m] } (a_i + b_j) \cdot \mu( A_i \cap B_j ). \end{aligned} φ+ψ∫φ+ψ​=i∈[n],j∈[m]∑​(ai​+bj​)⋅1Ai​∩Bj​​=i∈[n],j∈[m]∑​(ai​+bj​)⋅μ(Ai​∩Bj​).​

By rearranging the term on the right hand side, and by finite additivity of μ\muμ, we get the desired result.

□\square□

Bounded Functions

Let E∈FE \in \mathcal{F}E∈F be bounded with μ(E)≤∞\mu(E) \le \inftyμ(E)≤∞.
Let fff be a function whose support Supp(f)⊂E\mathbb{Supp} (f) \subset ESupp(f)⊂E and suppose that fff is bounded on EEE, i.e., ∃M>0\exists M > 0∃M>0, s.t., ∀ω∈E,∣f(ω)∣≤M\forall \omega \in E, | f (\omega) | \le M∀ω∈E,∣f(ω)∣≤M.
It holds that

∫Ef=∫f=sup⁡φ≤f∫φ \int_E f = \int f = \sup_{ \varphi \le f } \int \varphi ∫E​f=∫f=φ≤fsup​∫φ

where φ\varphiφ ranges over all simple functions.

Lemma. Suppose Supp(f)⊂E\mathbb{Supp}(f) \subset ESupp(f)⊂E and fff is bounded on EEE. Then fff is measurable if and only if

sup⁡φ≤f∫φ=inf⁡ψ≥f∫ψ \sup_{\varphi \le f } \int \varphi = \inf_{ \psi \ge f } \int \psi φ≤fsup​∫φ=ψ≥finf​∫ψ

where φ\varphiφ and ψ\psiψ ranges over all simple functions.

Proof. If sup⁡φ≤f∫Eφ=inf⁡ψ≥f∫Eψ\sup_{\varphi \le f } \int_E \varphi = \inf_{ \psi \ge f } \int_E \psisupφ≤f​∫E​φ=infψ≥f​∫E​ψ, then we can find a sequence of φn,ψn\varphi_n, \psi_nφn​,ψn​, such that ∫E(φn−ψn)→0\int_E (\varphi_n - \psi_n) \rightarrow 0∫E​(φn​−ψn​)→0. Let φ=sup⁡nφn\varphi = \sup_n \varphi_nφ=supn​φn​ and ψ=inf⁡nψn\psi = \inf_n \psi_nψ=infn​ψn​. It must be the case that φ=ψ a.e.\varphi = \psi \, a.e.φ=ψa.e.. Otherwise, ∃ϵ>0\exists \epsilon > 0∃ϵ>0 and a set A⊂EA \subset EA⊂E, such that φ−ψ>ϵ\varphi - \psi > \epsilonφ−ψ>ϵ on AAA. As the integration for simple functions is monotone,

∫φn−ψn≥∫ϵ⋅1A>ϵμ(A)>0. \int \varphi_n - \psi_n \ge \int \epsilon \cdot \mathbf{1}_A > \epsilon \mu(A) > 0. ∫φn​−ψn​≥∫ϵ⋅1A​>ϵμ(A)>0.

If fff is measurable, we need to prove that there are simple functions φ≤f≤ψ\varphi \le f \le \psiφ≤f≤ψ whose integrals are arbitrary close. For all ϵ>0\epsilon > 0ϵ>0, we can find a finite collection of disjoint intervals {(ai,bi]}\{ (a_i, b_i] \}{(ai​,bi​]} of length less than ϵ\epsilonϵ, such that it covers [−M,M][-M, M][−M,M]. Define Ei=f−1((ai,bi])E_i = f^{-1} \big( (a_i, b_i] \big)Ei​=f−1((ai​,bi​]) and let φ≐∑iai1Ei\varphi \doteq \sum_i a_i \mathbf{1}_{ E_i }φ≐∑i​ai​1Ei​​ and ψ≐∑ibi1Ej\psi \doteq \sum_i b_i \mathbf{1}_{ E_j }ψ≐∑i​bi​1Ej​​. Then ∫Eψ−∫E≤ϵ⋅μ(E)\int_E \psi - \int_E \le \epsilon \cdot \mu(E)∫E​ψ−∫E​≤ϵ⋅μ(E). It concludes that sup⁡φ≤f∫Eφ≤inf⁡ψ≥f∫Eψ\sup_{\varphi \le f } \int_E \varphi \le \inf_{ \psi \ge f } \int_E \psisupφ≤f​∫E​φ≤infψ≥f​∫E​ψ. The other direction of the inequality is trivial.

□\square□

Linearity. The integral on E∈FE \in \mathcal{F}E∈F with μ(E)≤∞\mu(E) \le \inftyμ(E)≤∞ is linear on the vector space of bounded and measurable functions.

Proof. Let f,g:E→Rf, g: E \rightarrow \mathbb{R}f,g:E→R is measurable and bounded. Clearly ∫c⋅f=c⋅∫f\int c \cdot f = c \cdot \int f∫c⋅f=c⋅∫f for all c∈Rc \in \mathbb{R}c∈R. It is left to verify that ∫f+g=∫f+∫g\int f + g = \int f + \int g∫f+g=∫f+∫g. First,

sup⁡ϕ≤f+g∫ϕ≥sup⁡φ≤f,ψ≤g∫φ+ψ=sup⁡φ≤f,ψ≤g(∫φ+∫ψ)=sup⁡φ≤f∫φ+sup⁡ψ≤g∫ψ , \begin{aligned} \sup_{ \phi \le f + g} \int \phi &\ge \sup_{ \varphi \le f, \psi \le g} \int \varphi + \psi \\ &= \sup_{ \varphi \le f, \psi \le g} \left( \int \varphi + \int \psi \right) = \sup_{ \varphi \le f} \int \varphi + \sup_{ \psi \le g} \int \psi \,, \end{aligned} ϕ≤f+gsup​∫ϕ​≥φ≤f,ψ≤gsup​∫φ+ψ=φ≤f,ψ≤gsup​(∫φ+∫ψ)=φ≤fsup​∫φ+ψ≤gsup​∫ψ,​

where the second equality follows from that integral for simple functions are linear. Similarly,

inf⁡ϕ≤f+g∫ϕ≤inf⁡φ≤f,ψ≤g∫φ+ψ=inf⁡φ≤f,ψ≤g(∫φ+∫ψ)=inf⁡φ≤f∫φ+inf⁡ψ≤g∫ψ . \begin{aligned} \inf_{ \phi \le f + g} \int \phi &\le \inf_{ \varphi \le f, \psi \le g} \int \varphi + \psi \\ &= \inf_{ \varphi \le f, \psi \le g} \left( \int \varphi + \int \psi \right) = \inf_{ \varphi \le f} \int \varphi + \inf_{ \psi \le g} \int \psi \,. \end{aligned} ϕ≤f+ginf​∫ϕ​≤φ≤f,ψ≤ginf​∫φ+ψ=φ≤f,ψ≤ginf​(∫φ+∫ψ)=φ≤finf​∫φ+ψ≤ginf​∫ψ.​

□\square□

Remark: In the proof we use the fact that for all subset A,B⊂RA, B \subset \mathbb{R}A,B⊂R, it holds that sup⁡a∈A,b∈B(a+b)=sup⁡a∈Aa+sup⁡b∈Bb\sup_{a \in A, b \in B} (a + b) = \sup_{a \in A} a + \sup_{b \in B} bsupa∈A,b∈B​(a+b)=supa∈A​a+supb∈B​b.

Nonnegative Functions

Let f:Ω→R≥0f : \Omega \rightarrow \mathbb{R}_{\ge 0}f:Ω→R≥0​ be a nonnegative function.
Then ∫f=sup⁡0≤h≤f∫h\int f = \sup_{0 \le h \le f} \int h∫f=sup0≤h≤f​∫h, where hhh ranges over all nonnegative bounded functions with finite support.
Formally,

∫f≐sup⁡{∫h:0≤h≤f, h is bounded,μ(Supp(h))<∞} \int f \doteq \sup \left\{ \int h : 0 \le h \le f,\, \begin{array}{ll} &h \text{ is bounded},\\ &\mu\big( \mathbb{Supp}(h) \big) < \infty \end{array} \right\} ∫f≐sup{∫h:0≤h≤f,​h is bounded,μ(Supp(h))<∞​}

It is easy to see that this definition is consistent with definition ♡\heartsuit♡.

Linearity. The integral is linear on the vector space of positive functions.

Proof 1. Let f,g:Ω→R≥0f, g: \Omega \rightarrow \mathbb{R}_{\ge 0}f,g:Ω→R≥0​ be nonnegative functions.
Clearly ∫c⋅f=c⋅∫f\int c \cdot f = c \cdot \int f∫c⋅f=c⋅∫f for all c∈Rc \in \mathbb{R}c∈R.
It is left to verify that ∫f+g=∫f+∫g\int f + g = \int f + \int g∫f+g=∫f+∫g. First,

sup⁡h≤f+g∫h≥sup⁡h1≤f,h2≤g∫h1+h2=sup⁡h1≤f,h2≤g(∫h1+∫h2)=sup⁡h1≤f∫h1+sup⁡h2≤g∫h2 , \begin{aligned} \sup_{ h \le f + g} \int h &\ge \sup_{ h_1 \le f, h_2 \le g} \int h_1 + h_2 \\ &= \sup_{ h_1 \le f, h_2 \le g} \left( \int h_1 + \int h_2 \right) = \sup_{ h_1 \le f} \int h_1 + \sup_{ h_2 \le g} \int h_2 \,, \end{aligned} h≤f+gsup​∫h​≥h1​≤f,h2​≤gsup​∫h1​+h2​=h1​≤f,h2​≤gsup​(∫h1​+∫h2​)=h1​≤fsup​∫h1​+h2​≤gsup​∫h2​,​

where the second equality follows from that integral for bounded functions with finite support are linear. To prove the reverse direction, for each bounded function 0≤h≤f+g0 \le h \le f + g0≤h≤f+g, let h1=min⁡{f,h}h_1 = \min \{ f, h\}h1​=min{f,h} and h2=h−h1h_2 = h - h_1h2​=h−h1​. Clearly 0≤h1≤f0 \le h_1 \le f0≤h1​≤f. On the other hand, 0≤h2=h−h1≤h−min⁡{f,h}=max⁡{h−f,0}≤g0 \le h_2 = h - h_1 \le h - \min \{ f, h \} = \max \{ h - f, 0 \} \le g0≤h2​=h−h1​≤h−min{f,h}=max{h−f,0}≤g. Hence,

∫h=∫h1+∫h2≤∫f+∫g. \int h = \int h_1 + \int h_2 \le \int f + \int g. ∫h=∫h1​+∫h2​≤∫f+∫g.

Taking supremum over hhh finishes the proof.

□\square□

Proof 2. There is another proof. If we examine the proof of monotone convergence theorem，we can see that it does not rely on linearity of integral.
It turns out that we can rely on it to prove linearity of nonnegative functions.
Let φn↑f\varphi_n \uparrow fφn​↑f and ψn↑g\psi_n \uparrow gψn​↑g be two sequences of nonnegative simple functions.
Using monotone convergence theorem, we get

lim⁡∫φn=∫f,lim⁡∫ψn=∫g,lim⁡∫φn+ψn=∫f+g. \begin{aligned} \lim \int \varphi_n = \int f, \qquad \lim \int \psi_n = \int g, \qquad \lim \int \varphi_n + \psi_n = \int f + g. \end{aligned} lim∫φn​=∫f,lim∫ψn​=∫g,lim∫φn​+ψn​=∫f+g.​

Then using only linearity of integration for simple function, we get

lim⁡∫φn+ψn=lim⁡∫φn+lim⁡∫ψn. \lim \int \varphi_n + \psi_n = \lim \int \varphi_n + \lim \int \psi_n. lim∫φn​+ψn​=lim∫φn​+lim∫ψn​.

□\square□

General Functions

Linearity. The integral is linear on the vector space of integrable general functions.

Proof. Let f,g:Ω→Rf, g: \Omega \rightarrow \mathbb{R}f,g:Ω→R be integrable functions.

For each c∈R+c \in \mathbb{R}_+c∈R+​, via the definition of integration,

∫c⋅f=∫cf+−∫cf−=c(∫f+−∫f−)=c∫f. \int c \cdot f = \int c f_+ - \int c f_- = c \left( \int f_+ - \int f_- \right) = c \int f. ∫c⋅f=∫cf+​−∫cf−​=c(∫f+​−∫f−​)=c∫f.

For each c∈R−c \in \mathbb{R}_-c∈R−​, via the definition of integration,

∫c⋅f=∫(−c)⋅f−−∫(−c)⋅f+=(−c)⋅(∫f−−∫f+)=c∫f. \int c \cdot f = \int (-c) \cdot f_- - \int (-c) \cdot f_+ = (-c) \cdot \left( \int f_- - \int f_+ \right) = c \int f. ∫c⋅f=∫(−c)⋅f−​−∫(−c)⋅f+​=(−c)⋅(∫f−​−∫f+​)=c∫f.

It is left to verify that ∫f+g=∫f+∫g\int f + g = \int f + \int g∫f+g=∫f+∫g.
First,

∫∣f+g∣≤∫∣f∣+∣g∣=∫∣f∣+∫∣g∣<∞. \int |f + g| \le \int |f| + |g| = \int |f| + \int |g| < \infty. ∫∣f+g∣≤∫∣f∣+∣g∣=∫∣f∣+∫∣g∣<∞.

It follows that f+gf + gf+g is integrable.
Observe

(f+g)+−(f+g)−=f+−f−+g+−g− ,(f+g)−−(f+g)+=f−−f++g−−g+ . (f + g)_+ - (f + g)_- = f_+ - f_- + g_+ - g_- \,, \\ (f + g)_- - (f + g)_+ = f_- - f_+ + g_- - g_+ \,. (f+g)+​−(f+g)−​=f+​−f−​+g+​−g−​,(f+g)−​−(f+g)+​=f−​−f+​+g−​−g+​.

Suppose that ∣f∣<∞|f| < \infty∣f∣<∞, and ∣g∣<∞|g| < \infty∣g∣<∞,
then clearly it holds that

(f+g)++f−+g−=f++g++(f+g)−. (f + g)_+ + f_- + g_- = f_+ + g_+ + (f + g)_-. (f+g)+​+f−​+g−​=f+​+g+​+(f+g)−​.

Suppose that f+g=∞f + g = \inftyf+g=∞.
Then 0≤(f+g)−≤∞0 \le (f + g)_- \le \infty0≤(f+g)−​≤∞.
And since f+gf + gf+g is well defined, we must have f(ω)≠−∞f(\omega) \neq -\inftyf(ω)=−∞ and g(ω)≠−∞g(\omega) \neq -\inftyg(ω)=−∞.
Therefore, 0≤f− , g−≤∞0 \le f_- \, , \, g_- \le \infty0≤f−​,g−​≤∞.
We can obtain

(f+g)++f−+g−=f++g++(f+g)−. (f + g)_+ + f_- + g_- = f_+ + g_+ + (f + g)_-. (f+g)+​+f−​+g−​=f+​+g+​+(f+g)−​.

Suppose that f+g=−∞f + g = -\inftyf+g=−∞.
Then 0≤(f+g)+≤∞0 \le (f + g)_+ \le \infty0≤(f+g)+​≤∞.
And since f+gf + gf+g is well defined, we must have f(ω)≠∞f(\omega) \neq \inftyf(ω)=∞ and g(ω)≠∞g(\omega) \neq \inftyg(ω)=∞.
Therefore, 0≤f+ , g+≤∞0 \le f_+ \, , \, g_+ \le \infty0≤f+​,g+​≤∞.
We can obtain

(f+g)−+f++g+=f−+g−+(f+g)+. (f + g)_- + f_+ + g_+ = f_- + g_- + (f + g)_+. (f+g)−​+f+​+g+​=f−​+g−​+(f+g)+​.

In all cases, we have

(f+g)++f−+g−=f++g++(f+g)−. (f + g)_+ + f_- + g_- = f_+ + g_+ + (f + g)_-. (f+g)+​+f−​+g−​=f+​+g+​+(f+g)−​.

Integrating for both side,

∫(f+g)++∫f−+∫g−=∫f++∫g++∫(f+g)−. \int (f + g)_+ + \int f_- + \int g_- = \int f_+ + \int g_+ + \int (f + g)_-. ∫(f+g)+​+∫f−​+∫g−​=∫f+​+∫g+​+∫(f+g)−​.

Rearranging terms finishes the proof.

□\square□
